awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Modeling and Control of Cellular Response to Dynamic Mechanical Manipulation Using a Dual-Input Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) project will create new models of the way that cells change their shape in response to external forces. The project will include the design of a dual-direction instrument for applying forces to cells -- one that combines a supporting surface that can expand and contract, together with a movable probe that can contact exposed portions of the cell surface. A control algorithm based on the new models will allow scientists and engineers to achieve precise stress and strain trajectories across the cell, and on specific organelles in the cell interior. This award will advance the national health, and promote the progress of the biological sciences. It will provide cell biologists with a new tool for studying the biochemical and mechanical changes that cells undergo in response to external forces, as well as a potential tool for inducing desired cell behaviors, for example, for the synthesis of biomaterials. Integrated educational and outreach activities include the development of new courses in nano-positioning and nano-biomechanics, and an outreach program on the use of nano-biomechanical methods in agriculture.

Mechanotransduction is the process of sensing, transmission and response to external mechanical stimuli of living cells. It is essential for maintenance of normal cell, tissue, and organ functioning. This project will build a suite of tools to sense and model cellular mechanotransduction dynamics and 3D dynamic structure, in order to achieve cellular behavior manipulation. The specific objectives of this project are to: (1) build a dual-direction mechanotransduction characterization scheme, which for the first time, uses both scanning probe microscopy and dynamic substrate stimuli and synchronizes optical and biomechanical quantification in biomechanical quantification; (2) create a new optimal excitation force design technique to incorporate and allow linear poroelasticity and nonlinear time-varying viscoelasticity models to be utilized in identification of mechanotransduction dynamics; and (3) formulate a near real-time precision tracking control algorithm to achieve high-efficiency tracking of the varying manipulation force to minimize the initial tracking error and tracking iterations by combining both iterative learning-based control and model predictive control approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
The CAREER project built a suite of dynamics- and control-based tools to sense and model the cellular mechanotransduction dynamics and 3D dynamic structure in order to achieve cellular behavior manipulation.  To date, the poor knowledge of cellular dynamics and lack of precise force control are still the key challenges towards high efficiency behavior manipulation and material synthesis of life science materials. By leveraging our expertise, resources, and collaborations, the PI has engaged in solving these challenging problems by achieving the following research objectives: (1) built a dual-direction dynamics sensing and modeling scheme to formulate a mathematical model of cellular dynamics and to create a 3D cellular structure model; (2) created a mechanotransduction manipulation methodology based on the outcome of (1) with near real-time precise force tracking for cellular mechanical behavior manipulation; and (3) implemented and evaluated the proposed mechanotransduction manipulation scheme on live cells that belong to different categories using an optical–scanning probe microscope (oSPM) system at nano- and micro-scale.

To study the cellular mechanotransduction dynamics, a dual-direction biomechanical sensing and modeling scheme was built, which combines both SPM mechanical quantification and electroactive polymer (EAP) substrate actuators to achieve accurate mechanical characterization of live cells. The top-down cellular mechanical characterization was achieved using the SPM probes to exert forces and measure the probe-sample interaction force. The bottom-up cellular mechanical characterization was performed using cell culture substrates with different morphology and also using deformable substrates build with EAP. The live cytoskeleton morphology was quantified using optical microscopy and machine learning (ML) algorithms we developed. Finally, the correction between cellular cytoskeleton statues and cell mechanical behavior, such as Young's modulus and poroelasticity, was modeled using a deep learning neural network we developed.

Meanwhile, to ensure the SPM quantification accuracy, control tools were built to guarantee that the desired forces can be exerted at the desired locations on the cells. ML models were adapted for system identification of the SPM system and used for model-based controller design. With the seamless integration of ML modeling and real-time feedback control approaches , such as model predictive control, the complex SPM nonlinear dynamics and system uncertainties were compensated. Thus, SPM performance was improved significantly in terms of both accuracy and speed. 

The integrated education efforts of this project is helping educating the next generation of control scientists and engineers working in the field of biomechanical synthesis and manipulation. The PI exploits the multidisciplinary nature of the research to recruit and retain female and under-represented students at both undergraduate and graduate levels. The education activities also benefits community college, K-12 students, as well as general public learners interested in both the dynamics and control and biomedical fields. The multidisciplinary domain of this research provides unique research opportunities for all groups of students.


Last Modified: 11/14/2024
Modified by: Juan Ren
